page.title: 05BIRDS ON THE COAST
page.content: On the Sefton shoreline vast areas of mudflat and sandbank are exposed when the tide goes out.Large flocks of wading birds feed in winter on the foreshore between the Ribble Estuary in the north and Liverpool to the south.Oystercatchers,Sanderling, turnstone and redshank are likely to be seen on the beach at high tide. Black-headed, herring,lesser black- backed and common gulls can be seen gathering to roost at dusk.The foreshore is part of the Southport Bird Sanctuary, which includes the nearby Ribble Estuary, and is an internationally important area because of its flocks of wintering and passage birds.These migrating birds include many species of wildfowl and waders,as well as several species of tern.Large flocks of the rare pink footed goose fly over and roost in this area.
